historicalFigures.name: Tunku Abdul Rahman
historicalFigures.background: Tunku Abdul Rahman was the first Prime Minister of Malaysia. He led the negotiations for independence from the British Empire and is revered as the 'Father of Independence' (Bapa Kemerdekaan).
historicalFigures.legacy: Tunku is the beloved father of the nation. He represents a simpler, more tolerant era.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His image is ubiquitous. He is a symbol of unity.
modernInterpretations: His handling of the 1969 riots is debated.

historicalFigures.name: Mahathir Mohamad
historicalFigures.background: Mahathir Mohamad is a physician and politician who served as Prime Minister twice (1981-2003, 2018-2020). He is the architect of modern Malaysia's economic boom.
keyDecisions: Pegging the Ringgit during the Asian Financial Crisis.
achievements: Transformed Malaysia into an industrial nation.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mahathir is the builder of modern Malaysia. He is a giant of Asian politics.
quotes: To be a great nation, we must have great ambition.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The Petronas Towers are his monument. He defined the 'Asian Values' debate.
modernInterpretations: Criticized for his iron fist and racial policies.

historicalFigures.name: P. Ramlee
historicalFigures.nativeName: Teuku Zakaria bin Teuku Nyak Puteh (P. Ramlee)
historicalFigures.background: P. Ramlee was an actor, director, singer, and composer. He is the icon of Malay entertainment and a cultural legend.
keyDecisions: Moving to Singapore to join Shaw Brothers.
Returning to Kuala Lumpur (where he was underappreciated).
historicalFigures.legacy: P. Ramlee is the soul of Malaysia. His movies are watched by every generation.
quotes: Where is the flute, where is the drum?
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a national treasure. His humor is timeless.
modernInterpretations: His mistreatment in later years is a source of national guilt.

historicalFigures.name: Hang Tuah
historicalFigures.background: Hang Tuah was a legendary warrior and admiral of the Malacca Sultanate. He is the archetype of Malay loyalty and martial prowess.
keyDecisions: Serving the Sultan with absolute loyalty.
Fighting his best friend Hang Jebat.
Kidnapping Tun Teja for the Sultan.
challenges: The fall of Malacca to the Portuguese (legend says he vanished).
historicalFigures.legacy: Hang Tuah is the Malay hero. 'Takkan Melayu Hilang di Dunia' (Malays will never vanish) is attributed to him.
quotes: Malays will never vanish from the earth.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the subject of the Hikayat Hang Tuah. A symbol of feudal loyalty.
modernInterpretations: His blind loyalty is sometimes questioned vs. Jebat's rebellion.

historicalFigures.name: Parameswara
historicalFigures.background: Parameswara was a prince from Palembang (Srivijaya) who fled to Temasek (Singapore) and then founded the Sultanate of Malacca.
keyDecisions: Founding Malacca under a Melaka tree.
achievements: Started the Golden Age of Malay culture.
historicalFigures.legacy: Parameswara is the father of the Malay Sultanates. Malacca became the center of the Malay world.
quotes: This place is suitable for a city.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the origin story of Malaysia.
modernInterpretations: His conversion to Islam is a key historical moment.

historicalFigures.name: Nicol David
historicalFigures.background: Nicol David is a former professional squash player. She was the world number one for a record-breaking 108 consecutive months.
keyDecisions: Dominating the sport for a decade.
achievements: Greatest squash player of all time.
challenges: Squash not being an Olympic sport.
historicalFigures.legacy: Nicol David is the queen of squash. She put Malaysia on the sporting map.
quotes: I just want to play my game.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a role model for women and youth.

historicalFigures.name: Lee Chong Wei
historicalFigures.background: Lee Chong Wei is a former badminton player. He was ranked first worldwide for 349 weeks and won three Olympic silver medals.
keyDecisions: Fighting back after a doping ban (accidental).
historicalFigures.legacy: Lee Chong Wei is the most successful Malaysian Olympian. He united the country through sport.
quotes: I'm sorry I couldn't bring back the gold.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is loved by all races in Malaysia.

historicalFigures.name: Anwar Ibrahim
historicalFigures.background: Anwar Ibrahim is the current Prime Minister of Malaysia. His career has been a rollercoaster of rising to power, imprisonment (Reformasi movement), and finally achieving the top office.
keyDecisions: Becoming PM after decades of struggle.
historicalFigures.legacy: Anwar is the survivor of Malaysian politics. His cry of 'Reformasi' changed the political landscape.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a polarizing but central figure.
modernInterpretations: His premiership is the test of his ideals.

historicalFigures.name: Yap Ah Loy
historicalFigures.background: Yap Ah Loy was the third Kapitan Cina of Kuala Lumpur. He is credited with developing Kuala Lumpur from a mining settlement into a major commercial center.
keyDecisions: Rebuilding KL after the Civil War.
historicalFigures.legacy: Yap Ah Loy built KL. Without him, the capital might be elsewhere.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Jalan Yap Ah Loy is named after him.
modernInterpretations: His role is sometimes downplayed in official history.

historicalFigures.name: Lat
historicalFigures.background: Lat is a cartoonist known for his 'Kampung Boy' series. His work captures the essence of Malaysian life, bridging racial and cultural divides with humor.
historicalFigures.legacy: Lat is the eyes of Malaysia. He reminds Malaysians of their shared humanity.
quotes: A kampung is a state of mind.

historicalFigures.name: Tun Fatimah
historicalFigures.background: Tun Fatimah was a queen of the Malacca Sultanate. She is known for her beauty, wisdom, and tragic life, as her family was executed by the Sultan before she married him.
keyDecisions: Marrying Sultan Mahmud Shah (who killed her family).
Ensuring her son succeeded the throne.
achievements: Mother of the Perak and Johor dynasties.
challenges: Execution of her father and husband (first).
historicalFigures.legacy: Tun Fatimah is a symbol of resilience. She secured the future of the Malay royalty.
quotes: The hand that rocks the cradle rules the world.
modernInterpretations: Her story is a tragedy of feudalism.

historicalFigures.name: Jimmy Choo
historicalFigures.background: Jimmy Choo is a fashion designer best known for his handmade women's shoes. He co-founded the Jimmy Choo brand, which became a global luxury icon.
keyDecisions: Co-founding the brand with Tamara Mellon.
Selling his share and focusing on education.
challenges: Loss of control of his name.
historicalFigures.legacy: Jimmy Choo is the most famous Malaysian name in fashion. His shoes are legendary.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He put Malaysia on the fashion map.
modernInterpretations: He is a mentor to young designers.

historicalFigures.name: Siti Nurhaliza
historicalFigures.background: Siti Nurhaliza is a singer and businesswoman. She is the 'Voice of Asia' and the most successful Malaysian artist of all time.
keyDecisions: Performing at the Royal Albert Hall.
historicalFigures.legacy: Siti is Malaysia's sweetheart. She is the gold standard of Malaysian music.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is loved by all generations.

historicalFigures.name: Mokhtar Dahari
historicalFigures.background: Mokhtar Dahari was a footballer known as 'Supermokh'. He is one of the top international scorers of all time (89 goals), beating legends like Puskas.
keyDecisions: Scoring against Arsenal and England B.
challenges: Motor neuron disease (ALS) - cause of death.
historicalFigures.legacy: Supermokh is the greatest Malaysian footballer. His record speaks for itself.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a legend. A musical was made about him.

historicalFigures.name: Sybil Kathigasu
historicalFigures.background: Sybil Kathigasu was a Eurasian nurse who supported the resistance during the Japanese occupation of Malaya. She was tortured but refused to betray the guerrillas.
historicalFigures.legacy: Sybil is the bravest woman in Malaysian history. Her sacrifice is legendary.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her clinic in Papan is a memorial.
modernInterpretations: Her story is a testament to the human spirit.

historicalFigures.name: Adnan Saidi
historicalFigures.background: Lieutenant Adnan was a Malay soldier who led the defense of Bukit Chandu (Opium Hill) against the Japanese invasion of Singapore. He fought to the death.
historicalFigures.legacy: Adnan is the epitome of courage. 'Biar putih tulang, jangan putih mata' (Better death than dishonor).
quotes: We will fight to the last man.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His story is taught in schools.

historicalFigures.name: Ungku Aziz
historicalFigures.background: Ungku Aziz was a prominent economist and academic. He founded Tabung Haji (Pilgrims Fund) and was the first Malaysian Vice-Chancellor of the University of Malaya.
historicalFigures.legacy: Ungku Aziz changed the economic fate of the Malays. Tabung Haji is a global model.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the father of Islamic finance in Malaysia.
modernInterpretations: His contribution to society is immeasurable.

historicalFigures.name: Tony Fernandes
historicalFigures.background: Tony Fernandes is the founder of AirAsia. He bought the failing airline for 1 Ringgit and turned it into the world's best low-cost carrier, democratizing air travel.
historicalFigures.legacy: Tony changed how Asians travel. He is the face of Malaysian entrepreneurship.
